name: Profanity and Sexualized Language
description: Profanities are often viewed as culturally impolite, crude, or offensive. Even when used in common or non-sexual contexts, sexually derived or sexualized profanities can be inappropriate, especially for minors. We aim to protect teenagers from exposure to such language while allowing some profanity in limited cases for artistic contexts and other benign usage.

categories.name: Sexually Vulgar Language
categories.description: Phrases or words that are anatomically or sexually derived

subcategories.name: Targeting Identifiable Individuals
subcategories.description: Sexually vulgar language directed at specific identifiable individuals

subcategories.name: Targeting Based on Protected Characteristics
subcategories.description: Sexually vulgar language targeting individuals or groups based on protected characteristics

subcategories.name: Sexual Solicitation/Explicit Context
subcategories.description: Sexually vulgar language used in context of sexual solicitation or when sexually explicit/suggestive
examples: DM me to suck my dick
Looking for someone to fuck tonight

subcategories.name: Any Other Context
subcategories.description: Sexually vulgar language in general contexts not covered above
conditions: Not targeting individuals or protected groups

subcategories.name: Commercial Music
subcategories.description: Sexually vulgar language in commercial music
conditions: Profanity is part of artistic expression

labelHierarchy.label: PSL > Sexually Vulgar > Targeting Protected Characteristics
PSL > Sexually Vulgar > Sexual Solicitation Context

exceptions.name: Commercial Music
exceptions.description: Sexually vulgar language appearing in commercial music productions

exceptions.name: Condemnation
exceptions.description: Content condemning the use of sexually vulgar language

exceptions.name: Educational or Awareness Raising
exceptions.description: Content sharing or discussing information for educational purposes or to improve understanding of an issue with public interest value

exceptions.name: News Reporting
exceptions.description: Sharing reliable information from news outlets, journalists, with aim to increase situational awareness about events

exceptions.name: Health Context
exceptions.description: Content discussing, informing, or educating about health-related issues such as human anatomy or disease

exceptions.name: Fully Censored
exceptions.description: Words that are fully starred, bleeped, silenced, or blurred out

exceptions.name: Acronyms
exceptions.description: Acronyms that could stand for vulgar words but don't spell the word itself

exceptions.name: Proper Names / Brands
exceptions.description: Names of person, group, location, event, brand, or media title that happen to spell the same as vulgar words

exceptions.name: Single Letters
exceptions.description: Single letters that could be initials

exceptions.name: Emojis Only
exceptions.description: Vulgar sentiment expressed only through emojis

exceptions.name: Non-Sexually Vulgar Profanity
exceptions.description: Words that are profane but not sexually derived are not covered under this policy
exceptions.note: Refer to Bullying & Harassment and Hateful Conduct policies if targeted

glossary.sexually_vulgar_phrases_words: Phrases or words that are anatomically or sexually derived (e.g., suck my balls, eat my dick, blow my cock, dick, fuck, pussy, motherfucker, cocksucker). Designated through marketized lists
glossary.awareness_raising: Sharing, discussing or reporting information to improve understanding of an issue with public interest value. Should not aim to incite violence, spread hate or misinformation. Includes citizen journalism
glossary.health_context: Content shared to discuss, inform, or educate about health-related issues such as human anatomy or disease (anorexia, dermatological conditions, cancer)
glossary.news_reporting: Sharing reliable information from news outlets, journalists to increase situational awareness about events. Subject to editorial standards, does not glorify or incite hostility
glossary.partially_obfuscated: Variations like 'f**k' where part of the word is visible - these STILL qualify as vulgar
glossary.fully_censored: Fully starred (****), bleeped, silenced, or blurred - these do NOT qualify as vulgar
glossary.misspelled_variations: Intentional misspellings like 'fack' still qualify as sexually vulgar
glossary.combined_words: Multi-word phrases written as single word (suckmydick) should be treated as the phrase (suck my dick)
glossary.split_words: Single vulgar words split into two (mother fucker) should be read as one word (motherfucker)

operationalGuidelines.hierarchy: 1) Targeting individuals, 2) Targeting protected characteristics, 3) Sexual solicitation context, 4) General context
operationalGuidelines.variations_that_qualify: Spelled incorrectly (fack), Partially obfuscated (f**k with some letters visible), Combined phrases (suckmydick), Split words (mother fucker)
operationalGuidelines.variations_that_dont_qualify: Proper names/brands, Fully censored (****), Acronyms (WTF, FML, AF), Single letters, Emojis only (ðŸ–•)
operationalGuidelines.non_marketized_languages: For markets without designated list, leverage English list as reference with appropriate translations
operationalGuidelines.marketized_lists: Markets with existing designated lists should refer exclusively to their market-specific exhaustive list
operationalGuidelines.policy_wide_exceptions: Always check for: Condemnation, Educational/Awareness, News reporting, Health context, Commercial music
